courseTitle: Introduction to the College of Sciences
courseDescription: Presents the relationship between majors in the College of Sciences and the student's career goals for students planning to major in a science.  Provides an orientation to the University emphasizing the learning skills needed for science majors.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of scientific studies to career goals
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration in a scientific academic setting
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizational skills for scientific academic work

courseDescription: This course outlines the history of science from Aristotle to the present.  Scientific progress has always been coupled with human progress and subject to the politics and culture of the times.  Scientists, in most instances, have been in the mainstream of society.  But, because of their curiosity and innovation, scientists have often clashed with the prevailing culture. (Cross-listed with HIST 386T).
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and debate of historical scientific theories
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of historical and scientific texts
Understanding the connection between science and society
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Balancing curiosity and innovation with societal norms
Understanding the role and influence of scientists in society

courseDescription: Responsible conduct of research is essential to good science and promoting public confidence in scientific knowledge.  This course will introduce students to responsible conduct of science and scientific research by exploring ethical and professional principles associated with the practice of research.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of ethical guidelines in scientific research
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Promoting public confidence in scientific knowledge
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification of ethical dilemmas in research

courseTitle: Research Methods in Math and Sciences
courseDescription: Emphasizes the tools and techniques used to solve scientific problems. Topics include use and design of experiments, use of statistics to interpret experimental results,mathematical modeling of scientific phenomena, and oral and written presentation of results. Students will perform four independent inquiries, combining skills from mathematics and science to solve research problems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of scientific tools and techniques
Use of statistics to interpret experimental results
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem solving using mathematics and science
